questions.question: What are the ligands used in the synthesis of hosts H1 and H2?
questions.answer: Ligands L1 and L2 are used in the synthesis of hosts H1 and H2, respectively.

questions.question: Which metal is selected for coordination in the formation of metallomacrocycles and why?
questions.answer: Silver (Ag) is selected for coordination in the formation of metallomacrocycles due to its pronounced ability to form two-coordination linear complexes.

questions.question: What types of anions were used in the study for the synthesis of the receptors, and which anion showed the most favorable binding energy with both hosts?
questions.answer: NO3-, BF4-, and TsO- anions were used in the study, and the TsO- anion showed the most favorable binding energy with both hosts.

questions.question: How does the synthesis approach of ligand L2 differ from that of ligand L1?
questions.answer: The synthesis of ligand L2 involves using 1,4,7-triazaheptane instead of propane-1,3-diamine, which is used in the synthesis of ligand L1.

questions.question: What role do the N-H groups play in the interaction with anions within the hosts?
questions.answer: The N-H groups provide suitably strong N-H donors for hydrogen bonding with the anions, facilitating their incorporation into the hosts.

questions.question: Why were water molecules found in the solid state structure of the 2BF4-@H2 complex?
questions.answer: Water molecules were present in the solid state structure of the 2BF4-@H2 complex to connect the N-H groups with the anions through bifurcated H-bonds, indicating a different interaction compared to other complexes.

questions.question: Is the formation of a macrocycle observed with the BF4- anion in the case of host H1?
questions.answer: No, the formation of a macrocycle is not observed with the BF4- anion in the case of host H1; instead, an infinite chain of alternating L1 ligands and Ag(I) ions is formed.

questions.question: Do the optimized geometries of the complexes match the experimental solid state structures?
questions.answer: Yes, the geometries of the optimized complexes are in rather good agreement with those of the experimental solid state structures.

questions.question: Are additional Ag+ ions coordinated to the pyrimidine rings in the solid state structure of the 2NO3-@H2 complex?
questions.answer: Yes, in the X-ray crystal structure of the 2NO3-@H2 complex, there are additional Ag+ metal centers bridging the pyrimidine rings that were not considered in the theoretical study.

questions.question: Does the presence of water molecules in the 2BF4-@H2 complex lead to the anions being located closer to the Ag+ ion compared to other complexes?
questions.answer: No, in the 2BF4-@H2 complex, despite the presence of water molecules, the anions form a bifurcated H-bond with two water molecules and are located at 3.05 Å from the Ag+ ion, indicating a different interaction pattern.

questions.question: Is the interaction energy for the complexation of anions always more favorable in vacuum than in water?
questions.answer: Yes, the interaction energies for the complexation of anions are always more favorable in vacuum than in water, as shown in the theoretical analysis.

questions.question: Does the synthesis of all complexes involve refluxing the ligand with Ag+ salts in water?
questions.answer: Yes, the synthesis of all complexes involves refluxing the respective ligand with Ag+ salts of BF4-, NO3-, and TsO- in water.

questions.question: Are the N-H groups and charged metal centers arranged in a way that is conducive to the formation of metallomacrocycles?
questions.answer: Yes, the particular arrangement of N-H and N coordinating atoms of pyrimidine rings is conducive to the formation of metallomacrocycles able to incorporate anions into the cavity.

questions.question: What is the significance of using DFT calculations in the theoretical study of the optimized complexes?
questions.answer: DFT calculations were used in the theoretical study to validate the design of the receptors and complexes, providing insights into the interaction energies and geometries of the optimized complexes.

questions.question: How does the ability of BF4- to establish anion-π interactions with heteroaromatic rings coordinated to transition metals affect the formation of the macrocycle?
questions.answer: The ability of BF4- to establish anion-π interactions, combined with its poor metal-coordination ability, likely complicates the formation of the macrocycle, leading to the formation of an infinite chain instead.

questions.question: What is the role of additional Ag+ ions in the solid state structure of the complexes?
questions.answer: Additional Ag+ ions in the solid state structure of the complexes play a crucial role in bridging pyrimidine rings, interacting with anions, and influencing the overall geometry and stability of the complexes.

questions.question: Are the ligands L1 and L2 based on aminopyrimidine rings?
questions.answer: Yes, the ligands L1 and L2 are based on aminopyrimidine rings connected by a spacer, with L2 including an additional aminopyrimidine ring.

questions.question: Does the experimental geometry confirm the ability of the self-assembled host to interact with two anions simultaneously?
questions.answer: Yes, the experimental geometry confirms the ability of the self-assembled host to interact with two anions simultaneously, combining hydrogen bonding and electrostatic forces.

questions.question: Is the interaction energy for the complexation of TsO- anions the most favorable among all studied anions?
questions.answer: Yes, for both hosts, the TsO- anion presents the most favorable binding energy among all studied anions.

questions.question: Does the presence of water molecules in the 2BF4-@H2 complex indicate a unique interaction pattern compared to other complexes?
questions.answer: Yes, the presence of water molecules in the 2BF4-@H2 complex, connecting the N-H groups with the anions through bifurcated H-bonds, indicates a unique interaction pattern compared to other complexes.
